Award.AwardTitle: ARTS: Collaborative Research: A model systematic treatment of a hyper-diverse lineage descended from early land plants (Frullania, Frullaniaceae, Marchantiophyta).
Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers will conduct a modern and novel taxonomic treatment of a hyper-diverse group of early land plants the liverwort genus Frullania. Liverworts (Marchantiophyta) are pivotal in our understanding of early land plant evolution and exist as important components of the vegetation in many regions of the world. The project represents an unprecedented investigation of this scale on a leafy liverwort genus, so-called because of the leafy plant structure. Taxonomic conclusions will be drawn from a multi-faceted data set, including morphology, fieldwork, experimental growth studies, as well as DNA sequence data, and population studies using DNA microsatellite markers.

Importantly, the project will extensively utilize computer and web-based tools to help furnish biodiversity data to biologists, ecologists, conservationists, and the public. The project continues strong partnerships with international databasing activities such as the Encyclopedia of Life. The project provides critical training to young scientists in museum collections-based research. Unique to the project is the development of a strong network of institutions, participating in Service to Science and Service Learning programs bridging science and training. The project has a strong outreach strategy including pod and video casts, contributing to Plants of the World Educator Guide, and participation in the Educator Open House, including over 300 Chicago-area educators. The scientists involves in this research will also provide a liverwort identification field course.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Liverworts (Marchantiophyta) are part of the plant group known as bryophytes. Bryophytes include liverworts, hornworts, and mosses. Despite the small size of these plants, bryophytes are important contributors to the world biodiversity and include over 20,000 species worldwide. They are the second largest group of land plants after flowering plants, and the earliest surviving plant group that colonized land. Bryophytes play crucial roles in understanding how plants first colonized land. Bryophyte communities play extremely important roles in the environment: they store significant amount of carbon, play key roles in ecosystem water retention and plant succession after disturbance, and provide microhabitats for a large diversity of organisms such as nitrogen-fixing bacteria, single-cell eukaryotes (bacteria) and protozoans, and many groups of invertebrate animals. The fungi that liverworts interact with are critical to forest health and growth, including economically important plantations used for wood and paper production. Many species are sensitive to air pollution and changes in water availability and are thus important environmental indicators. Some liverworts (including our focal group, Frullania) are known to cause human allergies and respiratory diseases. Liverworts have a rich metabolism, producing compounds of pharmaceutical interest, some of which have, for example, antibiotic properties.

Frullania is one of the most diverse liverwort genera with over 2000 published names and with a worldwide distribution. Knowing the species in this group allows scientists to take advantage of the unique capabilities of liverworts described above, and to better understand mechanisms that help create and maintain biodiversity on the planet. We tested species circumscriptions, and relationships among species, utilizing the plant morphology, experimental cultures, geographic distributions, and DNA sequence data, in a group called Microfrullania. We discovered species new to science and clarified many historically uncertain species boundaries. We were able to resolve relationships among almost all species in the group, which enabled us to understand their migration history in deeper geologic times. We found signals of both diversification on islands, and recent long-distance migration among continents and islands. These processes are critical for a better understanding of the ecological, economic, and medical impacts of these organisms.

This research has led to four peer-reviewed scientific publications, and generated data for two additional publications currently in preparation. It provided training in areas of plant biology, museum collections-based research, and computer science for two post-doctoral associates and several undergraduate students. The project contributed almost 2000 dried plant specimens to herbaria in the U.S.A. and abroad, including contributions to biodiversity data accessible online on the bryophyteportal.org. Herbarium collections such as these provide the raw materials for other researchers who undertake continuing research. As such, archiving plant collections saves future money by making research materials available to future generations of scientists. An online Citizen Science project, MicroPlants, to help discover biodiversity has had over 10,000 participants so far. A liverwort identification field course was offered for the public to encourage knowledge about these relatively poorly known organisms.
